solution:
We compute the first few powers of $\mathbf{A}$:
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \\
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Then
\[\mathbf{A}^{100} = (\mathbf{A}^3)^{33} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{A} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
model_solution:
To find $\mathbf{A}^{100}$, we'll first find $\mathbf{A}^3$ to see if there is a pattern.

\[\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]

This is the identity matrix $\mathbf{I}$.

We can use this to find $\mathbf{A}^{100}$.

Since $\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{I}$, then $\mathbf{A}^{99} = (\mathbf{A}^3)^{33} = \mathbf{I}^{33} = \mathbf{I}.$

Then $\mathbf{A}^{100} = \mathbf{A}^{99} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{I} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{I} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{A}$.

So $\mathbf{A}^{100} = \mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
